He is an advocate for integrating environment and development to ensure [[sustainable development]] in [[India]].<ref name=autogenerated3>{{cite web|url=http://caod.oriprobe.com/articles/32401492/The_Narmada_Water_Resources_Project_India_Implementing_Sustainable_Dev.htm|title=The Narmada Water Resources Project,India:Implementing Sustainable Development|author=Afroz Ahmad|work=oriprobe.com|accessdate=22 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite web|url=http://eurekamag.com/research/011/470/011470801.php|title=The Narmada Water Resources Project, India: Implementing sustainable development|author=Ahmad, Afroz|date=21 August 1999|work=eurekamag.com|accessdate=22 October 2015}}</ref>
Before joining Indian service in 1985 he was in [[United Nations]] Germany.On 5 December 2014, Ahmad was appointed Member ([[Environmental policy|Environment]] & [[Land rehabilitation|Rehabilitation]]) of the Narmada Control Authority, [[Ministry of Water Resources (India)]] Government of India<ref>http://www.nca.gov.in/bio-data/bio-group-a/bio-mem-enr.htm</ref> By prime minister of India after the approval of cabinet committee.In 2018 October Afroz Ahmad appointed member of National Wetland Committee Government Of India.
==Career== [[File:Modi ji.jpg|thumb|Afroz Ahmad discussing Narmada Rehabilitation issue with [[Narendra Modi]], presently [[Prime Minister of India]] on July 22, 2006.]]
In December 2014, Ahmad was appointed Member ([[Environmental science|Environment]] & Rehabilitation) in the Narmada Control Authority, Ministry of Water Resources, River Development and Ganga Rejuvenation within the [[government of India]].<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://nca.gov.in/ncambr_list.htm|title=NARMADA CONTROL AUTHORITY|work=nca.gov.in|accessdate=22 October 2015}}</ref> Before assuming charge as Member, he was Director (Impact Assessment & Rehabilitation) in the Narmada Control Authority.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sacw.net/article4881.html|title=India: Action Alert! Act fast to stop planned Uttarakhand in Narmada|work=sacw.net|accessdate=22 October 2015}}</ref>
Ahmad has also worked for the G. B. Pant Institute of Himalayan Environment and Development, [[Ministry of Environment and Forests (India)]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=apRpjwrIUkwC&pg=PR15|title=Perspective Resource Management In Developing Countries: Vol. 3 Ecological ...|work=google.co.in|accessdate=22 October 2015}}</ref>
==Personal life== Afroz Ahmad married Begum Sadiya Yasmin(Afroz), daughter of poet and Politician [[Bekal Utsahi]]. Sadiya is a poetess and social worker.<ref>http://www.freepressjournal.in/indore/sur-kavya-raas-leela-today/143587</ref>
==Publications== Ahmad is author of over 100 research papers, articles and reports on environmental management, sustainable development, policy planning, and human rehabilitation, including three papers published by [[The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]]. Some notable publications are:
*Assessment of Environmental Impacts of Sarda Sahayak Canal Irrigation Project of Uttar Pradesh Government, India. Int. Int. J. The Environmentalist, ENGLAND,Vol.10, No.4, pp. 281–298, 1990.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snowleopardnetwork.org/bibliography/Ahmad_1990.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Environmentalist |volume=10 |date=1990 |issn=0251-1088 |publisher=Snowleopardnetwork.org |accessdate=2015-10-22}}</ref> *Application of Environmental Impact Assessment in Himalayas: An Ecosystem approach for resources conservation and sustainable development. AMBIO, The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences (selectors of Nobel Laureates), Stockholm, SWEDEN, Vol.22, No.1, pp. 4–9, February, 1993.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freepaperdownload.us/1758/Article4881256.htm|title=[PDF]Environmental impact assessment in the Himalayas: an ecosystem approach: A. Ahmad, Ambio, 22(1), 1993, pp 4–9-Free Paper Download-FreePaperDownload.us|work=freepaperdownload.us|accessdate=22 October 2015}}</ref> *Environmental Impact Assessment for sustainable development: Chittaurgarh Irrigation Project in Outer Himalayas. AMBIO, The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, SWEDEN, Vol.20,No.7, pp. 298–302, November 1991.<ref>{{cite journal|jstor=4313849|title=Environmental Impact Assessment for Sustainable Development: Chittaurgarh Irrigation Project in Outer Himalayas|author1=Afroz Ahmad|author2=P. U.N. (UNEP)'s Desertification Control Bulletin, No.21, Nairobi, KENYA, pp. 15–23, 1992.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ahmad, Afroz |url=http://documentacion.ideam.gov.co/cgi-bin/koha/opac-detail.pl?biblionumber=24706&shelfbrowse_itemnumber=25888 |title=Biblioteca IDEAM catalog › Details for: Environmental degradation and possible solutions for restoring the land: |publisher=Documentacion.ideam.gov.co |date= |accessdate=2015-10-22}}</ref> *Rehabilitation of the displaced – A comprehensive Policy Approach. (2004). Victorian Literature and the Anorexic Body. UK: Cambridge University Press. pp. 38 & 48. {{ISBN|0-511-03051-7}}</ref> The advent of bikinis in 1946,<ref>[http://www.glamoursurf.com/articles/article/4918259/114188.htm The Two Piece Swimsuit Evolution]. (2004) "The Sari", Lustre press / Roli books;</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Grange Official says Optimism Prevails about India's Future|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3cghAAAAIBAJ&sjid=W6AFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5155,2461517&dq=midriff+saree&hl=en|accessdate=20 March 2012|newspaper=Reading Eagle|date=Apr 6, 1969}}</ref> Indian women have traditionally worn [[sari]]s that bares the midriff, especially [[South India]]n women.<ref name= Roshan>Alkazi, Roshan (1983) "Ancient Indian costume", Art Heritage;</ref><ref name= Ghurye>Ghurye (1951) "Indian costume", Popular book depot (Bombay)</ref> The exposure of midriff in a sari is considered to be erotic.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Khushwant Singh|title=Sex, Scotch & Scholarship|date=2012|publisher=HarperCollins Publishers|isbn=9350292424|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=biYlQLVNhOsC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Sex+Scotch+and+Scholarship&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UwPOVNfTNqTxmAWl94GABQ&ved=0CBwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=navel&f=false}}</ref> The midriff is revealed in other traditional female attires like [[Gagra choli|Ghagra choli]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=W7c8TBQhoAIC&pg=PA148&dq=lehenga+saree&hl=en&ei=J1VjTvuNEZTUgAfvvuGsCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CGEQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q&f=false Social Science a Textbook in History for Class IX as per New Syllabus - FK Publications]</ref> Belly chain known as kamarband in India when worn with [[Low-rise (fashion)|low-rise]] saris and [[lehenga]]s are considered sensuous.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Priyanka Dasgupta|title=Vidya Balan inspires Rituparna Sengupta?|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news/Vidya-Balan-inspires-Rituparna-Sengupta/articleshow/9964782.cms|accessdate=29 May 2016|work=The Times of India|date=Sep 13, 2011}}</ref> Most Indian women wear belly chains during weddings and other ceremonies as a show of culture and tradition. Nowadays, women have been pairing these chains with western outfits, mostly to draw attention to their figures.<ref name ="ind"/>
Men are intrigued by the demure floor-length attire and tantalising display of a bare midriff in the back.<ref>{{cite news|last=NOVIA MCDONALD-WHYTE|title=Unfolding the Indian Sari|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/magazines/allwoman/30276_Unfolding-the-Indian-Sari---|accessdate=20 March 2012|newspaper=Jamaica Observer|date=August 12, 2002|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140114064249/http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/magazines/allwoman/30276_Unfolding-the-Indian-Sari---#|archive-date=2014-01-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Some Indian women too tend to get aroused on getting pinched on their midriff bared by the sari.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rachel Vara|title=What's With Indian Men And The Navel Fetish?|url=https://onmogul.com/stories/what-s-with-indian-men-and-the-navel-fetish|website=onmogul.com|accessdate=5 June 2016}}</ref> This scenario was depicted in an advertising campaign for a leading constructions company group in India.<ref>{{cite web|title=KGS Corporate|url=http://www.kgscorporate.com/|website=kgscorporate.com|accessdate=5 June 2016}}</ref> With the tagline "Everything you love, is in arm's reach", it featured a man at office extending his arm out to pinch his wife's midriff at home, with her expressing joy by smiling and biting her lower lip.<ref>{{cite web|title=KGS Sunnyside Advertising Campaign|url=http://identitidesign.com/portfolio/kgs-sunnyside-advertising-campaign/|website=identitidesign.com|accessdate=5 June 2016}}</ref> It was featured as a full page advertisement in Dec 6, 2013 Chennai issue of the ''[[Times of India]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=KGS AD|url=http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Repository/getimage.dll?path=TOICH/2013/12/06/3/Img/Pg003_60.png|website=epaper.timesofindia.com|publisher=Times of India}}</ref>

{{short description|Equipment for estimating fish populations}}
[[File:Divers inspecting a stereo BRUVS frame at Rheeder's ReefP2277076.JPG|thumb|Divers inspecting a Stereo BRUV during sea trials by the South African Environmental Observation Network]] [[File:Stereo BRUVS in action at Rheeders Reef P2277038.JPG|thumb|Stereo BRUV prototype deployed at the Tsitsikamma National Park Marine protected area]] [[File:Stereo BRUV prototype on trial at Rheeders' Reef, Tsitsikamma P2277041.JPG|thumb|Stereo BRUV prototype on trial at Rheeders' Reef, Tsitsikamma]] '''Baited remote underwater video''' (BRUV) is a system used in [[marine biology]] research. By attracting fish into the field of view of a remotely controlled camera, the technique records [[fish diversity]], [[Abundance (ecology)|abundance]] and [[Ethology|behaviour]] of species. Sites are sampled by video recording the region surrounding a baited canister which is lowered to the bottom from a surface vessel or less commonly by a [[submersible]] or [[remotely operated underwater vehicle]]. The video can be transmitted directly to the surface by cable, or recorded for later analysis.
Baited cameras are highly effective at attracting [[scavenger]]s and subsequent [[Predation|predators]],<ref>Wilson RR Jr, Smith KL Jr (1984) Effect of near-bottom currents on detection of bait by the abyssal grenadier fishes Coryphaenoides spp., recorded in situ with a video camera on a free vehicle. Mar Biol 84:83–91, Henriques C, Priede IG, Bagley PM (2002) Baited camera observations of deep-sea demersal fishes of the northeast Atlantic Ocean at 15–28° N off West Africa. Mar Biol 141: 307–314, in Raymond, Erika H. & Widder, Edith A.''Behavioral responses of two deep-sea fish species to red, far-red, and white light.'' Marine Ecology Progress Series, Vol. 350: 291–298, 2007 doi: 10.3354/meps07196</ref> and are a non-invasive method of generating relative [[Abundance (ecology)|abundance]] indices for a number of marine species.<ref>Brooks, Edward J. Sloman, Katherine A. Sims, David W. Danylchuk, Andy J. (2011) ''Validating the use of baited remote underwater video surveys for assessing the diversity, distribution and abundance of sharks in the Bahamas'' Endangered Species Research, Vol. 13: 231–243, doi: 10.3354/esr00331 https://www.academia.edu/718540/Are_baited_remote_underwater_video_surveys_BRUVS_an_alternative_to_conventional_longline_surveys_for_determining_the_diversity_and_relative_abundance_#</ref>
As a non-extractive technique, it offers a low environmental impact way of understanding changes in fish numbers and diversity over time. BRUV surveys were developed in Australia, and are now used around the world for a variety of projects. This is a low budget monitoring system that is less reliant on the availability of skilled labour and may make sustainable monitoring more practical, over the long term.<ref>''Baited remote underwater video (BRUV) survey of False Bay’s icthyofauna'' http://www.saeon.ac.za/enewsletter/archives/2013/february2013/doc01 accessed 3 June 2013</ref>
There are two main types of remote video technique which have been used to record [[reef fish]] populations. They can both be left free standing without the need of an operator. The first system uses one downward looking camera (D-BRUV), and the other uses either one (mono) or two (stereo) horizontally facing cameras (H-BRUV),<ref>Tim Langlois, Pascale Chabanet, Dominique Pelletier, Euan Harvey (2006) ''Baited underwater video for assessing reef fish populations in marine reserves'', SPC Fisheries Newsletter #118 – July/September 2006, 53</ref> and may use underwater lighting to illuminate the target area. Stereo BRUV recordings can use software analysis to determine the size of specimens.
The colour of the lighting used for video may influence behaviour of the target species.<ref>Raymond, Erika H. & Widder, Edith A.''Behavioral responses of two deep-sea fish species to red, far-red, and white light.'' Marine Ecology Progress Series, Vol. 350: 291–298, 2007 doi: 10.3354/meps07196</ref>

A '''bullwheel''' or '''bull wheel''' is a large [[wheel]] on which a [[rope]] turns, such as in a [[chairlift]]. In that application, the bullwheel that is attached to the [[Wiktionary:prime mover|prime mover]] is called the drive bullwheel, and the other is the return bullwheel.
Originally, ''bullwheel'' was an [[oil field]] term applied to the large wheel that turns the drum upon which the drilling line is wound in [[percussion drilling]].
The bullwheel began use in [[farm implements]] with the [[reaper]]. The term described the traveling wheel, traction wheel, drive wheel, or harvester wheel. The bullwheel powered all the moving parts of these farm machines including the reciprocating knives, reel, rake, and self binder. The bullwheel's outer surface provided traction against the ground and turned when the draft animals or [[tractor]] pulled the implement forward.<ref>{{Citation | title = Reaper Bull Wheel Improvements | url = http://www.machine-history.com/Reaper%20Bull%20Wheel%20Improvements | publisher = Machine-History.com | accessdate = 2012-08-21 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120325080847/http://www.machine-history.com/Reaper%20Bull%20Wheel%20Improvements | archivedate = 2012-03-25 | df = }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | title = Revolving Track Wheel for Binder Bull Wheel | url = http://www.machine-history.com/Revolving%20Track%20Wheel%20for%20Binder%20Bull%20Wheel | publisher = Machine-History.com | accessdate = 2012-08-21 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120611055608/http://www.machine-history.com/Revolving%20Track%20Wheel%20for%20Binder%20Bull%20Wheel | archivedate = 2012-06-11 | df = }}</ref> [[Cyrus McCormick]] used the bullwheel to power his 1834 reaper and until the early 1920s when small [[internal combustion engine]] gasoline engines like the [[Cushman (company)|Cushman Motor]]<ref>Breaking the Land: The Transformation of Cotton, Tobacco, and Rice Cultures Since 1880</ref> began to be favored.

Pennsylvania College for Women
Chatham College |athletics = [[NCAA Division III]] – [[Presidents' Athletic Conference|PAC]] |nickname = [http://www.gochathamcougars.com/ Cougars] |mascot = Carson the [[Cougar]]{{cite news|title=Athletics’ mascot gets a new name|url=http://www.chatham.edu/news/index.php/2011/03/athletics-mascot-gets-a-new-name|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140916145746/http://www.chatham.edu/news/index.php/2011/03/athletics-mascot-gets-a-new-name|dead-url=yes|archive-date=September 16, 2014|publisher=chatham.edu|date=March 31, 2011}} |colors = Purple and Gray[https://moodle.chatham.edu/pluginfile.php/59227/mod_resource/content/2/CU%20brand%20graphics%20guidelines_0715.pdf] {{color box|#521C78}} {{color box|#A3A699}} |affiliations = [[Annapolis Group]] |website = {{URL|www.chatham.edu}} |logo = Chatham University text logo.png }} {{coord|40.44917|N|79.92583|W|type:edu|display=title}} '''Chatham University''' is an American [[university]] that has [[coeducational]] academic programs through the doctoral level, with its main campus located in the [[Shadyside (Pittsburgh)|Shadyside]] neighborhood of [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]], United States. Chatham University maintains its Eastside Campus at the corner of Shadyside and the [[East Liberty (Pittsburgh)|East Liberty]] neighborhood of Pittsburgh.{{cite web|url=http://www.chatham.edu/about/eastside.cfm |title=Chatham Eastside | Chatham University, Pittsburgh, PA |website=Chatham.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-03-13}} This campus serves the Health Sciences and Architecture programs. In 2013, Chatham opened its Eden Hall Campus to house the Falk School of Sustainability and is located in the Pittsburgh suburb of Pine.{{cite web|url=http://www.chatham.edu/edenhall/ |title=Eden Hall Campus | Chatham University, Pittsburgh, PA |website=Chatham.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-03-13}} The current university student population of 2,110 includes 1,002 undergraduate students and 1,108 graduate students.{{cite web|title=Chatham Quick Facts|url=http://www.chatham.edu/about/quickfacts.cfm|accessdate=22 August 2017}} The University grants certificates and degrees including bachelor, master, first-professional, and doctorate in the School of Arts, Science, and Business, the School of Health Sciences, and the Falk School of Sustainability. ==History== Founded as the '''Pennsylvania Female College''' on December 11, 1869, by Reverend William Trimble Beatty (the father of renowned operatic [[contralto]] [[Louise Homer]]), Chatham was initially situated in the Berry mansion on Woodland Road off Fifth Avenue in the neighborhood of Shadyside. The campus today is composed of buildings and grounds from a number of former private mansions, including those of [[Andrew Mellon]], Edward Stanton Fickes, George M. Laughlin Jr. and James Rea. It was renamed '''Pennsylvania College for Women''' in 1890, and as '''Chatham College''' in 1955. The name served to honor [[William Pitt, 1st Earl of Chatham]] and namesake of the City of [[Pittsburgh]].[http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/f/findaid/findaid-idx?c=ascead;cc=ascead;q1=chatham%20university;rgn=main;view=text;didno=US-PPiU-dar192508 William Pitt Family Papers, 1757-1804], DAR.1925.08, [[The Darlington Collection]], Special Collections Department, University of Pittsburgh The school gained [[university]] status from the [[Pennsylvania Department of Education]] on April 23, 2007, and publicly announced its new status on 2007-05-01, changing its name to Chatham University.{{cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/07121/782468-100.stm|accessdate=2009-08-16|date=2007-05-01|first=Tim|last=Grant|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|title=Chatham gains university status}} With elements designed for the original Andrew Mellon estate by the [[Olmsted Brothers]], the {{convert|39|acre|ha|sing=on}} Chatham campus was designated an [[arboretum]] in 1998 by the American Association of Botanical Gardens and Arboreta. It features over 115 different varieties of species, including Japanese Flowering Crabapple, [[River Birch]] and [[Kentucky Coffee Tree]]. In 2005 the University expanded its programs to include online advanced degree programs (bachelors, masters, doctoral) through the School of Continuing Education, now the College for Continuing and Professional Studies. Two years later, Chatham's M.F.A. Program in Creative Writing was named one of the top five Innovative/Unique Programs by ''[[The Atlantic Monthly]]''.{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/doc/200708/mfa-programs|accessdate=2009-08-16|year=2007|publisher=The Atlantic Monthly|title=The Best of the Best|first=Edward J.|last=Delaney}} Chatham received some national attention in 2014 when it announced that it was engaging in a period of study "considering admitting men for the first time in that college's history,"{{cite web|last=Schackner |first=Bill |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/local/breaking/2014/02/18/Chatham-U-trustees-approve-resolution-to-study-going-all-coed/stories/201402180194 |title=Chatham University considers enrolling men as undergraduate students | Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |website=Post-gazette.com |date=2014-02-18 |accessdate=2017-03-13}} resulting in "reactions of surprise and anger" from its alumnae.{{cite web|last=Schackner |first=Bill |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/news/education/2014/02/19/Chatham-graduates-express-shock-at-possible-co-ed-move-wage-fight-to-keep-undergraduate-college-single-sex/stories/201402190157 |title=Coed possibility concerns Chatham alumnae | Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |website=Post-gazette.com |date=2014-02-19 |accessdate=2017-03-13}} ==Leadership== The current president of Chatham University is David Finegold, DPhil. Dr. Finegold, a graduate of Harvard University and a Rhodes Scholar who received his doctorate from Oxford University, became the 19th president in 2016,{{cite web|title=President's Bio|url=https://www.chatham.edu/about/presidents_bio.cfm|accessdate=22 August 2017}} following the retirement of [[Esther Barazzone|Dr. Esther Barazzone]] after a 24-year tenure. ==Campuses== The original Shadyside Campus is part of historic Woodland Road. The Shadyside Campus now includes Chatham Eastside,[http://www.chatham.edu/news/story.cfm?ID=316 Chatham.edu] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090421004254/http://www.chatham.edu/news/story.cfm?ID=316 |date=2009-04-21 }} which serves as the home for health science and architecture programs. The University's new {{convert|388|acre|ha|adj=on}} Eden Hall Campus is located north of the city in Richland Township, Pa. and is the home of Chatham's new Falk School of Sustainability. Programs at Eden Hall Campus include a BS/BA in Sustainability, a Masters in Sustainability, an MFA in Food Studies, and a dual degree Masters in Sustainability / Masters in Business Administration. The Eden Hall Campus was donated to Chatham University by the Eden Hall Foundation on May 1, 2008. In 2011, the University engaged the architectural team of Berkebile Nelson Immenschuh McDowell (BNIM) of Kansas City, Mo. and the landscape design firm Andropogon Associates of Philadelphia to lead the master planning process. The first phase of development, which won an award for sustainable development was completed by the firm Mithun in 2016.{{Cite news|url=http://mithun.com/project/chatham-university-eden-hall-campus/?from=featured|title=Chatham University Eden Hall Campus - Mithun|work=Mithun|access-date=2018-01-29|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.chatham.edu/news/index.php/2017/04/chatham-news/eden-hall-campus-receives-american-institute-of-architects-award-for-sustainable-design-excellence|title=Eden Hall Campus receives American Institute of Architects Award for Sustainable Design Excellence|date=2017-04-20|work=Chatham News|access-date=2018-01-29|language=en-US}} ==Academics== [[File:Chatham University - IMG 7665.JPG|thumb|right|Chatham University grounds]] [[File:Chatham University - IMG 7653.JPG|thumb|right|Campus [[labyrinth]]]] The University structure includes three distinctive Colleges: Chatham College houses academic and co-curricular programs for undergraduate men and women and embodies the traditions and rituals of the traditional liberal arts college. The College for Graduate Studies offers women and men both masters and doctoral programs. Programs within the College for Graduate Studies include concentrations in art and architecture, business, health sciences, teaching and creative writing. The College for Continuing and Professional Studies, formerly the School of Continuing Education, provides online and hybrid undergraduate and graduate degree programs for women and men, certificate programs, and community programming including the Summer Music and Arts Day Camp.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} ==Accreditation== Chatham University is accredited by the [[Middle States Commission on Higher Education]]. {{cite web|last1=Ltd.|first1=Info724|title=Middle States Commission on Higher Education|url=https://www.msche.org/institutions_directory.asp?txtRange=c|website=www.msche.org|accessdate=24 September 2017}} ==Public recognition== * Institution of Distinction, Association of American Colleges and Universities (2002) * Andrew Heiskell Award for Innovation in International Education: Internationalizing the Campus, presented by the Council for International Exchange of Scholars (2003) * A "Best College in the Mid-Atlantic" and "Best College in the Northeast," ''Princeton Review'' * ''Kaplan's Guide to the 328 Most Interesting Colleges and Universities'' * Member of the [[United Nations Academic Impact]]{{Cite web|url=https://academicimpact.un.org/sites/academicimpact.un.org/files/MEMBER%20LIST_02_JANUARY%202018_1.pdf|title=United Nations Academic Impact Members 2018|last=|first=|date=2018-01-02|website=academic impact|access-date=2018-01-30}} ==Outreach centers== * Center for Women's Entrepreneurship * Global Focus/International Programs * Pennsylvania Center for Women and Politics * Pittsburgh Teachers Institute * Rachel Carson Institute (honoring Rachel Carson, Class of 1929) ==International collaborations== * Kobe Women's College (Japan) * [[Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts]] (Japan) * Kyoto Women's College (Japan) * The American University (Rome) * Seoul Women's University (Korea) * Centre International des études françaises (Angers, France) * Institute of Central American Development Studies (Costa Rica) * The Center for Cross-Cultural Study – study abroad programs in Spain and Argentina ==Athletics== Chatham University teams, also known as the Cougars, participate as a member of the [[NCAA Division III]]. The Cougars are a member of the [[Presidents' Athletic Conference]] (PAC). Women's sports include basketball, cross country, ice hockey, soccer, softball, swimming & diving, tennis, track & field and volleyball. Men's and women's ice hockey play in the [[United Collegiate Hockey Conference]]. The women's ice hockey team was the first NCAA women's ice hockey team in Pennsylvania. The college mascot was previously Pennsy the Seal. The cougar mascot was adopted in 1992 and was named Carson in honor of alumna [[Rachel Carson]] in 2011. ==Notable alumnae== Among Chatham's notable alumnae is [[biologist]] and [[zoologist]] [[Rachel Carson]] (1929), after whom the Rachel Carson Institute at Chatham is named. The RCI, as it is known, promotes understanding of [[environmentalism|environmental]] issues through conferences, lectures, discussion panels, and other methods. In honor of Rachel Carson's legacy, the University President, Esther L. Barazzone, Ph.D. and others led a campaign to rename the Ninth Street Bridge in [[Downtown Pittsburgh]] as the [[Rachel Carson Bridge]]. The naming resolution was passed by [[Allegheny County, Pennsylvania|Allegheny County]] Council on December 6, 2005. The Rachel Carson Bridge is one of the "Three Sisters" Bridges, opened between 1926 and 1928, and designed by County architect Stanley L. Roush and the Allegheny County Department of Public Works. The [[Roberto Clemente Bridge]] (formerly Sixth Street Bridge) and the [[Andy Warhol Bridge]] (formerly Seventh Street Bridge) complete the trio of bridges. They are the only trio of nearly identical bridges and were the first self-anchored suspension spans built in the United States. They are among the only surviving examples of large [[eyebar]]-[[chain]] [[suspension bridge]]s in the country. Other notable alumnae include: *[[Catherine Chisholm Cushing]], playwright *[[Kathie L. Olsen]] ’74, Ph.D., past deputy director, [[National Science Foundation]] *[[Elaine Scarry]] Ph.D. ’68, author and Walter M. Cabot Professor of Aesthetics and the General Theory of Value at [[Harvard University]] *[[Lea Wait]] ’68, author of mystery novels, and children's books *[[Lesley B. Wells|Lesley Brooks Wells]] ’59, [[United States District Judge]] *[[Muriel Bowser]] '94, Mayor of Washington, D.C. 2015-,{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dc-politics/dc-mayor-elect-muriel-bowser-dc-council-members-to-be-sworn-in-friday/2015/01/01/ee6892ec-91fc-11e4-a412-4b735edc7175_story.html|date=January 2, 2015|publisher=The Washington Post|title=Muriel Bowser sworn in as D.C. mayor; pledges to make city healthier, safer|last1=DeBonis |first1=Mike |last2=Davis |first2=Aaron C. }} Washington, D.C. The [[De Doelen|Doelen]] conference center extends under part of the building. |motto = |motto_translation = |location = |streetaddress = |region = |city = Rotterdam |state = |province = |county = |country = Netherlands |coordinates = {{coord|51.922125|4.471733|display=inline, title}} |schooltype = |fundingtype = |type = |religious_affiliation = |religion = |denomination = |patron = |established = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> |founded = |opened = |founder = |status = |closed = |principal = |principal_label = |principal1 = |principal2 = |principal3 = |principal4 = |viceprincipal = |viceprincipal_label = |viceprincipal1 = |staff = |faculty = |teaching_staff = |employees = |key_people = |enrolment = |enrollment_as_of = |students = |international_students = |classes = |avg_class_size = |campus = |campus size = |area = |graduates = |affiliations = |alumni = |nobel_laureates = |information = |url = {{URL|http://www.codarts.nl/EN/}} |website = |footnotes = |picture = |picture_caption = |picture2 = |picture_caption2 = }} '''Codarts University for the Arts''' ({{lang-nl|Codarts hogeschool voor de kunsten}}) is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[vocational university]] in [[Rotterdam]] that teaches music, dance and circus. It was established in its present location in 2000.
==History==
Codarts can trace its origins to the Rotterdam Conservatorium voor Muziek (Rotterdam Conservatory of Music), popularly known as the Conservatorium Holthaus after its director, Jos Holthaus (1879-1943).<ref name=Bloeme/> In 1930 the alternative Rotterdamsch Toonkunst Conservatorium (Rotterdam Musical Arts Conservatory) was founded with the composer [[Willem Pijper]] as director.<ref name=Historici/> The Rotterdamse Dansschool (Rotterdam Dance School) was established in 1931 by [[Corrie Hartong]] as director and the German dancer [[Gertrud Leistikow]] as a teacher.<ref name=Historici/> At first the dance school was part of the Conservatorium Holthaus.<ref name=Bloeme/> In 1935 the dance school transferred to Pijper's conservatory. Hartong remained as director. She was to stay in this position until 1961, and continued to teach until 1967.<ref name=Historici/>
[[World War II]] broke out in 1939 and the Netherlands were invaded in May 1940. On 14 May 1940 the buildings of the dance school and the main building of Pijper's conservatory were destroyed by bombs. It was decided to merge Pijper's and Holthaus's conservatories into one building on Mathenesserlaan, where Holthaus had a branch. Soon they moved again to a big old house that had somehow been spared, totally surrounded by rubble, and managed to continue day classes and early evening classes before curfew throughout the remainder of the war. Until Holthaus died in 1943 the combined conservatory had two directors.<ref name=Bloeme/>
The Rotterdamse Dansschool was renamed the Rotterdamse Dansacademie (Rotterdam Dance Academy) in 1954. In 1986 the Conservatory and Dance Academy became the Hogeschool voor Muziek en Theater Rotterdam (Rotterdam University of Music and Theatre).<ref name=Bloeme/> The school moved into its present modern building next to the [[De Doelen|Doelen]] concert hall in 2000 under the name Codarts - hogeschool voor de kunsten (Codarts - University of the Arts).<ref name=Hoogstad/> The Circus arts program was launched in September 2006.<ref name=selfgeneral/>
==Schools== [[File:Codarts Big Band, conducted by Ilja Reijngoud.jpg|thumb|Codarts Big Band, conducted by [[Ilja Reijngoud]], at the [[North Sea Jazz Festival]], July 2008]] Codarts has three divisions: the Rotterdam Conservatory, Rotterdam Dance Academy, and Rotterdam Circus Arts.<ref name=selfgeneral/>
The Rotterdam Conservatory is one of the largest conservatories in the Netherlands, with over 900 pupils. It offers courses through which students may obtain a bachelor's degree in any of several disciplines: Music Theater, Pop, Jazz, Composition/arranging, Music Production, Argentinean tango, Indian music, Flamenco, Latin/Latin jazz/Brazilian, Turkish music, Classical music, and Music in Education.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.codarts.nl/EN/music/content/info/CONS-080121-INFO-general_info.php |title=general information |publisher=Rotterdam Conservatory |accessdate=2012-05-05}}</ref> The school puts on public performances, at times using the adjacent [[De Doelen]] concert hall. Thus in April 2011 guest conductor [[Arie van Beek]] led the Codarts Orchestra and Codarts Chamber Choir in a performance in the Jurriaanse Hall.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dedoelen.nl/concerten/agenda/3020/codarts_orkest_en_codarts_kamerkoor// |title=Codarts Orkest en Codarts Kamerkoor |language=Dutch |publisher=De Doelen |date=April 11, 2012 |accessdate=2012-05-05}}</ref> In September 2011 the Codarts Ensemble performed a program that explored the boundary between classical music and jazz, with works by Stravinsky, Gershwin, Shostakovich, Antheil and Harvey.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dedoelen.nl/concerten/agenda/2692/codarts_ensemble// |title=Codarts Ensemble |language=Dutch |date=September 26, 2011 |publisher=De Doelen |accessdate=2012-05-05}}</ref> The Codarts Ensemble played again at De Doelen in March 2012 with the Codarts Chamber Choir, performing a major work by [[Arthur Honegger]]. They were conducted by [[Wiecher Mandemaker]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.rotterdam.info/visitors/events/12225/codarts-ensemble-codarts-chamber-choir/ |work=Rotterdam Info |title=CODARTS ENSEMBLE & CODARTS CHAMBER CHOIR |date=5 March 2012 |accessdate=2012-05-05}}</ref>
The Dance Academy teaches dancers and arranges for students to appear in performances and tours. Codarts helps students gain practical experience with internships with noted dance companies, and participates in student exchange programs with other European and American dance schools.<ref name=selfgeneral/> In May 2011 the Rotterdam Dance Academy performed at the [[Venice Biennale]] with a show called ''Talent on the Move''. The program included works by established choreographers such as [[Jiří Kylián]], [[Nacho Duato]] and [[Mauro Bigonzetti]] and by younger artists including graduates of the academy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.labiennale.org/en/dance/archive/arsenale-della-danza/rotterdam-da.html?back=true |title=Rotterdam Dance Academy / Codarts (Netherlands) |date=May 15, 2011 |publisher=Biennale di Venezia |accessdate=2012-05-05}}</ref>
The Circus Arts school began offering a bachelor's course in September 2006, training students for careers in [[Contemporary circus|contemporary]] and traditional circus, in [[variety show]]s and in local or street theater.<ref name=selfgeneral/> Circus students learn dance and drama as well as a wide range of circus techniques to prepare for a professional career.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fedec.eu/rotterdam_circus_arts_codarts.2398.html |title=ROTTERDAM CIRCUS ARTS (RCA) - CODARTS |work=Fedec |accessdate=2012-05-05}}</ref>
The [[Havo voor Muziek en Dans]] (High School for Music and Dance) provides a secondary school education in which music and dance are part of the daily curriculum. It is co-located in the Codarts building and Codarts teachers teach the music and dance classes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hmd.nl/content/welkom/index.php |title=Havo voor Muziek en Dans |language=Dutch |publisher=Havo voor Muziek en Dans |accessdate=2012-05-03}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rotterdam.nl/eCache/TER/10/18/805.html |title=Havo/vwo voor muziek en dans |language=Dutch |work=ROTTERDAMWORLDPORTWORLDCITY |date=2006-01-19 |accessdate=2012-05-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304134705/http://www.rotterdam.nl/eCache/TER/10/18/805.html |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }}</ref> The school prepares students for higher music education, but graduates must still pass entrance examinations to continue at Codarts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://aecsite.cramgo.nl/DownloadView.aspx?ses=17773 |title=Overview of the musical pre-college phase in The Netherlands |publisher=AEC |accessdate=2012-05-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109140415/http://aecsite.cramgo.nl/DownloadView.aspx?ses=17773 |archivedate=2013-11-09 |df= }}</ref> The high school was the subject of the 2007 documentary ''[[De Droomfabriek]]'' (The Dream Factory) directed by [[Netty van Hoorn]]''.<ref name=Nfilmfest>{{cite web |url=http://www.filmfestival.nl/industry/films/de-droomfabriek |work=Netherlands Film Festival |title=De droomfabriek (The Factory of Dreams) |accessdate=2012-05-06}}</ref>
==Building== [[File:CodartsRotterdam2017.jpg|thumb|Codarts Rotterdam]] The building abuts the 1966 [[De Doelen]] concert and conference building, home of the [[Rotterdam Philharmonic Orchestra]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rpho.nl/concerten/concertgebouw-de-doelen/ |publisher=Rotterdam Philharmonic Orchestra |title=Concertgebouw de Doelen |language=Dutch |accessdate=2012-05-05}}</ref> It was built as part of an overall plan for an extension to De Doelen defined in 1993 by Jan Hoogstad. A new building site beside the Kruisplein was created by reducing the size of Karel Doormanstraat, and this was used for the Doelen extension and the Codarts building.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mimoa.eu/projects/Netherlands/Rotterdam/De%20Doelen |title=DE DOELEN |work=Mimoa |accessdate=2012-05-05}}</ref> The building was developed by the architectural firm of [[Jan Hoogstad|Ector Hoogstad]], and was completed in 2000. The plinth is mainly used for commercial purposes. The building is relatively high to accommodate all the demands of the school, and has a total floor space of {{convert|10500|m2}}. Visually, the Codarts building appears to reach over the end of the conference center.<ref name=Hoogstad/>
The building's steel skeleton supports a "box in box" design for the interior spaces, including several tall spaces with variable lighting. A long escalator connects the entrance lobby to the fifth floor. This is the main floor for Codarts, holding the restaurant, library and several performance rooms, and opening onto a terrace on the roof of the Doelen extension. Codarts occupies classrooms and offices below this floor. The conservatory is above it and the large dance studios are at the top of the building. The building is clad in brick to give an appearance consistent with nearby apartment buildings.<ref name=Hoogstad/>
==Notable alumni== * [[Henk van der Vliet]] (1950), Dutch composer and flautist * [[Willemijn Verkaik#cite note-Nieuws-1|Willemijn Verkaik]], Dutch theatre actress, best known for playing Elphaba from the musical [[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]] in the Netherlands, Germany, New York and London. * [[San Holo]], Dutch record producer and DJ.

{{refimprove|date=May 2018}}
Efforts to save endangered species may, paradoxically, lead to '''conservation-induced extinction''' of other species. This mostly threatens the parasite and pathogen species that are highly host-specific to critically endangered hosts. When the last individuals of a host species are captured for the purpose of captive breeding and reintroduction programs, they typically undergo anti-parasitic treatments to increase survival and reproductive success. This practice may unintentionally result in the extinction of the species antagonistic to the target species, such as certain parasites. It has been proposed that the parasites should be reintroduced to the endangered population. A few cases of conservation-induced extinction have occurred in parasitic [[lice]].<ref name="Rózsa2014">{{cite journal | last=Rózsa | first=Lajos | last2=Vas | first2=Zoltán | title=Co-extinct and critically co-endangered species of parasitic lice, and conservation-induced extinction: should lice be reintroduced to their hosts? | journal=Oryx | volume=49 | issue=01 | date=2014-08-22| doi=10.1017/s0030605313000628 | pages=107–110}}</ref>
==Examples==
* Parasite: ''[[Colpocephalum californici]]'' – host: [[California condor]]<ref name = Dunn>Dunn RR 2009. Coextinction: anecdotes, models, and speculation. In Holocene Extinctions (ed. S.T. Turvey), pp. 167–180. Oxford University Press, Oxford, UK.</ref> :The parasite most probably became extinct when the last individuals of its only host species were captured for a captive-breeding program; all parasites found were deliberately killed in an attempt to assist the host's survival.<ref name="Stringer2014">{{cite journal |last1=Stringer |first1=Andrew Paul |last2=Linklater |first2=Wayne |title=Everything in Moderation: Principles of Parasite Control for Wildlife Conservation |journal=BioScience |date=2014 |volume=64 |issue=10 |pages=932–937 |doi=10.1093/biosci/biu135 |doi-access=free}}</ref> * Parasite: ''Rallicola (Aptericola) pilgrimi'' – host: [[little spotted kiwi]]<ref name = Buckley>Buckley TR, Palma RL, Johns PM, Gleeson DM, Heath ACG, Hitchmough RA, Stringer IAN 2012. The conservation status of small or less well known groups of New Zealand terrestrial invertebrates. ''New Zealand Entomologist'' '''35:''' 137–143.</ref> :The parasite most probably became extinct when the last individuals of its only host species were captured and, after routine veterinary antiparasitic treatments, re-introduced into predator-free islands. * Parasite: ''Rallicola (Rallicola) guami'' – host: [[Guam rail]] :The only known host species of this parasite exists exclusively in captivity and kept under veterinary control. No information about the fate of the parasite, likely extinct. * Parasite: ''Linognathus petasmatus'' – host: [[scimitar-horned oryx]] :The host specificity of this parasite is uncertain. Either it was specific to the scimitar-horned oryx and became extinct during captive breeding of the host, or – alternatively – it may be specific to the [[addax]] and possibly still surviving in the wild.
==Erroneous example==
* “The Trichodectid lice of the [[black-footed ferret]]” has been mentioned in the literature several times<ref name = Gompper>Gompper ME, Williams ES 1998. Parasite conservation and the black-footed ferret recovery program. ''Conservation Biology'' '''12:''' 730–732.</ref> as a parasite that became extinct during the captive breeding program of the host. However, this parasite most probably never existed as a separate species.<ref name="Rózsa2014"/>
==Current example==
Parasite species that are specific to a single host species are endangered whenever the host is to be saved by captive breeding programs. A current example is the louse ''Felicola isidoroi'', a louse parasitizing the [[Iberian lynx]].<ref name = Felicola>Pérez, J.M.; Sánchez, I. & Palma, R.L. (2013). The dilemma of conserving parasites: the case of ''Felicola (Lorisicola) isidoroi'' (Phthiraptera: Trichodectidae) and its host, the endangered Iberian lynx (''Lynx pardinus''). ''Insect Conservation and Diversity'' '''6:''' 680–686.</ref>

Lett. | publisher = [[IOP Publishing]] | country = | frequency = Quarterly | history = 2006–present | openaccess = Yes | impact = 4.541 | impact-year = 2017 | website = http://iopscience.org/erl | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = | OCLC = | LCCN = | CODEN = ERLNAL | ISSN = 1748-9326 | eISSN = 1748-9326 }} '''''Environmental Research Letters''''' is a quarterly, [[peer review|peer-reviewed]], [[Open access (publishing)|open-access]], leading international [[scientific journal]] covering research in all aspects of [[environmental science]]. It is produced by [[IOP Publishing]]. '''''Environmental Research Letters''''' coverage reflects the increasingly interdisciplinary nature of environmental science, recognizing wide-ranging contributions to the development of methods, tools and evaluation strategies relevant to the field. Numerical modelling or simulation, as well as theoretical and experimental approaches to environmental science form the core content. Approaches from a range of [[Physical science|physical]] and [[natural science]]s, [[economics]], and [[Politics|political]], [[Sociology|sociological]] and [[legal studies]] are also present.
The [[editor-in-chief]] is [[Daniel Kammen]] ([[University of California, Berkeley]]).
Many of the journal's articles are also covered on IOP Publishing's web site.
