{{external media | width = 160px | align = upright | headerimage= [[File:Mexico.Tab.LaVenta.01.jpg|160px|alt=|link=]] | audio1 = [https://www.sciencehistory.org/distillations/podcast/grandmothers-matter "Grandmothers Matter: Some surprisingly controversial theories of human longevity"], [[Science History Institute]] }} The '''grandmother hypothesis''' is a hypothesis to explain the existence of [[menopause]] in human life history by identifying the adaptive value of extended kin networking. It builds on the previously postulated "[[Menopause#Mother hypothesis|mother hypothesis]]" which states that as mothers age, the costs of reproducing become greater, and energy devoted to those activities would be better spent helping her offspring in their reproductive efforts.{{Cite journal|last=Pavard|first=Samuel|last2=Metcalf|first2=C. Jessica E.|last3=Heyer|first3=Evelyne|date=5 March 2008|title=Senescence of reproduction may explain adaptive menopause in humans: A test of the "mother" hypothesis|url=|journal=American Journal of Physical Anthropology|doi=10.1002/ajpa.20794|pmid=18322919|access-date=|volume=136|pages=194–203}} It suggests that by redirecting their energy onto those of their offspring, grandmothers can better ensure the survival of their genes through younger generations. By providing sustenance and support to their kin, grandmothers not only ensure that their genetic interests are met, but they also enhance their social networks which could translate into better immediate resource acquisition.{{cite book|title=The Selfish Gene|last=Dawkins|first=Richard|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=1976|isbn=0-19-286092-5|location=[[New York City]]|authorlink=Richard Dawkins}}{{cite journal|last=Alexander|first=R.D.|year=1974|title=The Evolution of Social Behaviour|journal=Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics|volume=5|pages=325–83|doi=10.1146/annurev.es.05.110174.001545}} This effect could extend past kin into larger community networks and benefit wider [[Inclusive fitness|group fitness]].{{cite book|title=Human Evolution: An Introduction to Man’s Adaptations|last=Campbell|first=B.|publisher=Aldine|year=1971|isbn=0-202-02013-4}} == Background == One explanation to this was presented by [[George C. Williams (biologist)|G.C. Williams]] who was the first to posit{{cite journal|last=Williams|first=GC|year=1957|title=Pleiotropy, natural selection, and the evolution of senescence|journal=Evolution|volume=11|issue=4|pages=398–411|doi=10.2307/2406060|jstor=2406060}} that menopause might be an adaptation. Williams suggested that at some point it became more advantageous for women to redirect reproductive efforts into increased support of existing offspring. Since a female's dependent offspring would die as soon as she did, he argued, older mothers should stop producing new offspring and focus on those existing. In so doing, they would avoid the age-related risks associated with reproduction and thereby eliminate a potential threat to the continued survival of current offspring. The evolutionary reasoning behind this is driven by related theories. === Kin selection === {{Main|Kin selection}} Kin selection provides the framework for an adaptive strategy by which altruistic behavior is bestowed on closely related individuals because easily identifiable markers exist to indicate them as likely to reciprocate. Kin selection is implicit in theories regarding the successful propagation of genetic material through reproduction, as helping an individual more likely to share one's genetic material would better ensure the survival of at least a portion of it. Hamilton's rule suggests that individuals preferentially help those more related to them when costs to themselves are minimal. This is modeled mathematically as :
'''rb > c'''
Grandmothers would, therefore, be expected to forgo their own reproduction once the benefits of helping those individuals (''b'') multiplied by the relatedness to that individual (''r'') outweighed the costs of the grandmother not reproducing (''c''). Evidence of kin selection emerged as correlated with climate-driven changes, around 1.8 –1.7 million years ago, in female foraging and food sharing practices.{{cite journal|last=O’Connell|first=J.F.|year=1999|title=Grandmothering and the evolution of Homo erectus|journal=Journal of Human Evolution|volume=36|issue=5|pages=461–485|doi=10.1006/jhev.1998.0285|pmid=10222165|author2=Hawkes, K.|author3=Blurton Jones, N.G.}} These adjustments increased juvenile dependency, forcing mothers to opt for a low-ranked, common food source ([[tuber]]s) that required adult skill to harvest and process. Such demands constrained female IBIs thus providing an opportunity for selection to favor the grandmother hypothesis. === Parental investment === {{Main|Parental investment}} Parental investment, originally put forth by [[Robert Trivers]], is defined as any benefit a parent confers on an offspring at a cost to its ability to invest elsewhere.{{Cite book|title=Parental Investment and Sexual Selection|last=Trivers|first=Robert|publisher=Aldine Publishing Company|year=1972|isbn=|location=Chicago|pages=139}} This theory serves to explain the dynamic sex difference in investment toward offspring observed in most species. It is evident first in gamete size, as eggs are larger and far more energetically expensive than sperm. Females are also much more sure of their genetic relationship with their offspring, as birth serves as a very reliable marker of relatedness. This paternity uncertainty that males experience makes them less likely than females to invest, since it would be costly for males to provide sustenance to another male's offspring. This translates into the grandparental generation, as grandmothers should be much more likely than grandfathers to invest in the offspring of their children, and more so in the offspring of their daughters than sons. == The grandmother effect == [[Evolution|Evolutionary theory]] dictates that all organisms invest heavily in reproduction in order to replicate their genes. According to parental investment, human females will invest heavily in their young because the number of mating opportunities available to them and how many offspring they are able to produce in a given amount of time is fixed by the biology of their sex. This inter birth interval (IBI) is a limiting factor in how many children a woman can have because of the extended developmental period that human children experience. Extended childhood, like the extended post-reproductive lifespan for females, is unique to humans.{{cite journal|last=Hawkes|first=K.|year=1997|title=Hazda Women's Time Allocation, Offspring Provisioning, and the Evolution of Long Postmenopausal Life Spans|journal=Current Anthropology|volume=38|issue=4|pages=551–577|doi=10.1086/204646|author2=O’Connell, J.F.|author3=Blurton Jones, N.G.}} Because of this correlation, human grandmothers are well-poised to provide supplemental parental care to their offspring's children. Since their grandchildren still carry a portion of their genes, it is still in the grandmother’s genetic interest to ensure those children survive to reproduction. === Reproductive senescence === {{Main|Evolution of aging}} The mismatch between the rates of degradation of [[somatic cells]] versus [[gamete]]s in human females provides an unsolved paradox. Why do [[somatic cells]] decline at a slower rate and why do humans invest more in somatic [[longevity]] relative to other species?{{cite journal|last=Hawkes|first=K.|year=2003|title=Grandmothers and the evolution of human [[longevity]]|journal=American Journal of Human Biology|volume=15|issue=3|pages=380–400|doi=10.1002/ajhb.10156|pmid=12704714}} Since natural selection has a much stronger influence on younger generations, [[Mutation|deleterious mutations]] during later life become harder to select out of the population.{{Cite journal|last=Croft|first=Darren P.|last2=Brent|first2=Lauren J.N.|last3=Franks|first3=Daniel W.|last4=Cant|first4=Michael A.|date=July 2015|title=The evolution of prolonged life after reproduction|url=|journal=Trends in Ecology and Evolution|doi=10.1016/j.tree.2015.04.011|pmid=|access-date=|volume=30|pages=407–416}} In female [[Placentalia|placentals]], the number of ovarian [[oocytes]] is fixed during embryonic development, possibly as an adaptation to reduce the accumulation of [[mutations]],{{cite book|title=On Fertile Ground: Ecology, Evolution and Human Reproduction|last=Ellison|first=P.T.|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=2001}} which then mature or degrade over the life course. At birth there are, typically, one million [[Ovum|ova.]] However, by menopause, only approximately 400 eggs would have actually matured.{{cite journal|last=Baker|first=T.G.|year=1963|title=A quantitative and cytological study of germ cells in human ovaries.|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological Sciences|volume=158|issue=972|pages=417–433|doi=10.1098/rspb.1963.0055}} In humans, the rate of [[follicular atresia]] increases at older ages (around 38-40), for reasons that are not known.{{Cite journal|last=Hawkes|first=Kristen|last2=Smith|first2=Ken R.|date=25 August 2010|title=Do women stop early? Similarities in fertility decline in humans and chimpanzees|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|doi=10.1111/j.1749-6632.2010.05527.x|pmid=20738274|volume=1204|pages=43–53|pmc=4043631}} In chimpanzees, our closest nonhuman, genetic relatives, there is a very similar rate of oocyte atresia until the age of 35 at which point humans experience a far accelerated rate compared to chimpanzees.{{Cite journal|last=Cloutier|first=Christina T.|last2=Coxworth|first2=James|last3=Hawkes|first3=Kristen|date=5 February 2015|title=Age-related decline in ovarian follicle stocks differ between champanzees (Pan troglodytes) and humans|url=|journal=AGE|doi=10.1007/s11357-015-9746-4|pmid=|access-date=|volume=37|pmc=4317403}} However, chimpanzee females, unlike humans, usually die while still in their reproductive phase. The aging process in humans leaves a dilemma in that females live past their ability to reproduce. The question poised to evolutionary researchers then becomes, why do human bodies live on so robustly and for so long past their reproductive potential, and could there be an adaptive benefit to abandoning one's own attempts at reproduction to assist kin? === Alloparenting === The practice of dividing parenting responsibilities among non-parents affords females a great advantage in that they can dedicate more effort and energy toward having an increased number of offspring. While this practice is observed in several species,{{Cite journal|last=Leggett|first=Helen C.|last2=El Mouden|first2=Claire E|last3=Wild|first3=Geoff|last4=West|first4=Stuart|date=12 October 2011|title=Promiscuity and the evolution of cooperative breeding|url=|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society B|doi=10.1098/rspb.2011.1627|pmid=|access-date=|volume=279|pages=1405–1411|pmc=3282361}} it has been an especially successful strategy for humans who rely extensively on social networks. One observational study of the Aka foragers of Central Africa demonstrated how allomaternal investment toward an offspring increased specifically during times that the mother's investment in subsistence and economic activities increased.{{Cite journal|last=Meehan|first=Courtney|date=16 September 2009|title=Maternal Time Allocation in Two Cooperative Childrearing Societies|url=|journal=Human Nature|volume=20|issue=4|pages=375–393|doi=10.1007/s12110-009-9076-2|pmid=|access-date=}} If the grandmother effect were true, post-menopausal women should continue to work after the cessation of fertility and use the proceeds to preferentially provision their kin. Studies of [[Hadza people|Hadza]] women have provided such evidence. A modern hunter-gatherer group in Tanzania, the post-menopausal Hadza women often help their grandchildren by foraging for food staples that younger children are inefficient at acquiring successfully. Children, therefore, require the assistance of an adult to gain this crucial version of sustenance. Often, however, mothers are inhibited by the care of younger offspring and are less available to help their older children forage. In this regard, the Hadza grandmothers become vital to the care of existing grandchildren, and allow reproductive-age women to redirect energy from existing offspring into younger offspring or other reproductive efforts. However, some commentators felt that the role of Hadza men, who contribute 96% of the mean daily intake of protein, was ignored;{{cite journal|last=Gurven|first=M.|year=1997|title=Comments on 'Hazda Women's Time Allocation, Offspring Provisioning, and the Evolution of Long Postmenopausal Life Spans'|journal=Current Anthropology|volume=38|issue=4|pages=566–567|doi=10.1086/204646|author2=Hill, K.}} though the authors have addressed this criticism in numerous publications.{{cite journal|last=Hawkes|first=K.|year=2001|title=Hadza Meat Sharing|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|volume=22|issue=2|pages=113–142|doi=10.1016/S1090-5138(00)00066-0|pmid=11282309|author2=O'Connell, J.F.|author3=Blurton Jones N.G.}}{{cite journal|last=Hawkes|first=K.|year=2001|title=Hunting and nuclear families: some lessons from the Hadza about men's work|journal=Current Anthropology|volume=42|issue=5|pages=681–709|doi=10.1086/322559|author2=O'Connell, J.F.|author3=Blurton Jones N.G.}}{{cite journal|last=Hawkes|first=K.|year=2010|title=Provisioning is not the only reason men hunt|journal=Current Anthropology|volume=51|issue=2|pages=259–264|doi=10.1086/651074|author2=O'Connell, J.F.|author3=Coxworth, J.E.}} Other studies also demonstrated reservations about behavioral similarities between the Hadza and our ancestors.{{cite journal|last=Gibbons|first=A.|year=1997|title=Why Life After Menopause?|journal=Science|volume=276|issue=5312|page=535|doi=10.1126/science.276.5312.535b}} === Maternal v. paternal grandmothers === Because grandmothers should be expected to provide preferential treatment to offspring she is most certain of her relationship to, there should be differences in the help she provides to each grandchild according to that relationship. Studies have found that not only does the maternal or paternal relationship of the grandparent affect whether or how much help a grandchild receives, but also what kind of help. Paternal grandmothers often had a detrimental effect on infant mortality.{{cite journal|last=Voland|first=E.|year=2002|title=Opposite Effects of Maternal and Paternal Grandmothers on Infant Survival in Historical Krummörn|journal=Mpidr Wp 2001-026|author2=Beise, J.}}{{cite journal|last=Jamison|first=C.S.|year=2002|title=Are all grandmothers equal? A review and a preliminary test of the grandmother hypothesis in Tokugawa Japan|journal=American Journal of Physical Anthropology|volume=119|issue=1|pages=67–76|doi=10.1002/ajpa.10070|pmid=12209574|author2=Cornell L.L.|author3=Jamison P.L.|author4=Nakazato H.}} Also, maternal grandmothers concentrate on offspring survival, whereas paternal grandmothers increase birth rates.{{cite book|title=Grandmotherhood – the Evolutionary Significance of the Second Half of Female Life|last=Mace|first=R.|publisher=Rutgers University Press|year=2004|chapter=Are Humans Communal Breeders?|author2=Sear, R.|editors=Voland, E., Chasiotis, A. and Schiefenhoevel, W.}} These finding are consistent with ideas of parental investment and paternity uncertainty. Equally, a grandmother could be both a maternal and paternal grandmother and thus in division of resources, a daughter’s offspring should be favored. Other studies have focused on the genetic relationship between grandmothers and grandchildren. Such studies have found that the effects of maternal / paternal grandmothers on grandsons / granddaughters may vary based on degree of genetic relatedness, with paternal grandmothers having positive effects on granddaughters but detrimental effects on grandsons,{{cite journal|last=Fox|first=M|year=2010|title=Grandma plays favourites: X-chromosome relatedness and sex-specific childhood mortality|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society B|volume=277|issue=1681|pages=567–573|doi=10.1098/rspb.2009.1660|pmc=2842695|pmid=19864288|author2=Sear R|author3=Beise J|author4=Ragsdale G|author5=Voland E|author6=Knapp LA}} and paternity uncertainty may be less important than chromosome inheritance.{{cite journal|last=Fox|first=M|year=2011|title=The Selfish Grandma Gene: The Roles of the X-Chromosome and Paternity Uncertainty in the Evolution of Grandmothering Behavior and Longevity|journal=International journal of evolutionary biology|volume=1|pages=1–9|doi=10.4061/2011/165919|author2=Johow J|author3=Knapp LA}} == Criticisms and alternative hypotheses == Some critics have cast doubt on the hypothesis because while it addresses how grandparental care could have maintained longer female post-reproductive lifespans, it does not provide an explanation for how it would have evolved in the first place. Some versions of the grandmother hypothesis asserted that it helped explain the longevity of human [[senescence]]. However, demographic data has shown that historically rising numbers in older people among the population correlated with lower numbers of younger people.{{Cite journal|last=Hawkes|first=Kristen|date=11 March 2004|title=Human longevity: The grandmother effect|url=|journal=Nature|doi=10.1038/428128a|pmid=15014476|access-date=|volume=428|pages=128–129}} This suggests that at some point grandmothers were not helpful toward the survival of their grandchildren, and does not explain why the first grandmother would forgo her own reproduction to help her offspring and grandchildren. In addition, all variations on the mother, or grandmother effect, fail to explain [[longevity]] with continued [[spermatogenesis]] in males. Another problem concerning the grandmother hypothesis is that it requires a history of female [[philopatry]]. Though some studies suggest that hunter-gatherer societies are [[patriarchal]],{{cite journal|last=Peccei|first=J. S.|year=2001|title=A critique of the grandmother hypotheses: Old and new|journal=American Journal of Human Biology|volume=13|issue=4|pages=434–452|doi=10.1002/ajhb.1076|pmid=11400215}} mounting evidence shows that residence is fluid among hunter-gatherers{{cite book|title=Kinship and Behavior in Primates|last=Alvarez|first=H.|publisher=Oxford University|year=2004|location=Oxford|pages=420–442|chapter=Residence groups among hunter-gatherers: A view of the claims and evidence for patrilocal bands|editor=Chapais, B. |editor2=Berman, C}}{{cite journal|last=Marlowe|first=F|year=2004|title=Marital residence among foragers|journal=Current Anthropology|volume=45|issue=2|pages=277–284|doi=10.1086/382256|jstor=10.1086/382256}} and that married women in at least one patrilineal society visit their kin during times when kin-based support can be especially beneficial to a woman's [[reproductive success]].{{cite journal|last=Scelza|first=B.|year=2011|title=Female Mobility and Postmarital Kin Access in a Patrilocal Society|journal=Human Nature|volume=22|issue=4|pages=377–393|doi=10.1007/s12110-011-9125-5|pmid=22388944}} One study does suggest, however, that maternal kin were essential to the fitness of sons as fathers in a patrilocal society.{{Cite journal|last=Strier|first=Karen B.|authorlink=Karen B. Strier|last2=Chaves|first2=Paulo B.|last3=Mendes|first3=Sergio L.|last4=Fagundes|first4=Valeria|last5=Di Fiore|first5=Anthony|date=22 November 2011|title=Low paternity skew and the influence of maternal kin in an egalitarian, patrilocal primate|url=|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|doi=10.1073/p|pmid=|access-date=}} It also fails to explain the detrimental effects of losing ovarian follicular activity. While continued post-menopausal synthesis of estrogen occurs in peripheral tissues through the adrenal pathways,{{Cite journal|last=Labrie|first=F.|date=2010|title=DHEA, important source of sex steroids in men and even more in women|url=|journal=Neuroendocrinology: Pathological Situations And Diseases|volume=182|pages=97–148|doi=10.1016/S0079-6123(10)82004-7|pmid=|access-date=}} these women undoubtedly face an increased risk of conditions associated with lower levels of estrogen: [[osteoporosis]], [[osteoarthritis]], [[Alzheimer's disease]] and [[coronary artery disease]].{{cite journal|last=Massart|first=F.|year=2001|title=Genetics of Menopause-Associatred Diseases|journal=Maturitas|volume=40|issue=2|pages=103–116|doi=10.1016/S0378-5122(01)00283-3|pmid=11716989|author2=Reginster, J.Y.|author3=Brandi, M.L.}} Alternatively, the debilitating symptoms that usually accompany menopause in Western cultures could be seen as a natural cull of non-reproductive members of a species. Hot flashes, loss of short term memory, decreased ability to concentrate and difficulty in the learning of new tasks would, in the wild, leave the sufferer at greater risk from predators and topographical dangers such as falls from a height. This natural cull would leave more food, usually in relatively short supply, for the reproductive members of a species whose youth are less experienced at finding it. However, cross-cultural studies of menopause have found that menopausal symptoms are quite variable among different populations, and that some populations of females do not recognize, and may not even experience, these "symptoms".{{cite journal|last=Melby|first=Melissa K.|year=2005|title=Vasomotor symptom prevalence and language of menopause in Japan|journal=Menopause|volume=12|issue=3|pages=250–257|doi=10.1097/01.GME.0000146108.27840.D9|pmid=15879913}} This high level of variability in menopausal symptoms across populations brings into question the plausibility of menopause as a sort of "[[culling]] agent" to eliminate non-reproductive females from competition with younger, fertile members of the species. This also faces the task of explaining the paradox between the typical age for menopause onset and the life expectancy of female humans. == See also == * ''[[The How and the Why]]'' – a play based on the controversy surrounding the Grandmother hypothesis and the evolution of human reproduction * [[Postpartum confinement]], a worldwide tradition in which the grandmothers care for the next generation * [[Patriarch hypothesis]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Menstrual cycle}} {{Human Evolution}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Grandmother Hypothesis}} [[Category:Gerontology]] [[Category:Human evolution]] [[Category:Menopause]] [[Category:Middle age]]

{{Gravitational Lensing}} {{main|Gravitational lens}} {{cleanup|reason= encyclopedic style, verifiability, editing, transfer parentheses containing self-referential text '(How? There is no D_s...)' to talk page or delete.|date= October 2018}}
In [[general relativity]], a point mass deflects a light ray with [[impact parameter]] <math>b~</math> by an angle approximately equal to
<math>\hat{\alpha} = \frac{4GM}{c^2b}</math>
where G is the [[gravitational constant]], M the mass of the deflecting object and c the [[speed of light]]. A naive application of [[Newtonian gravity]] can yield exactly half this value, where the light ray is assumed as a massed particle and scattered by the gravitational potential well. This approximation is good when <math>4GM/c^2b</math> is small.
In situations where general relativity can be approximated by [[linearized gravity]], the deflection due to a spatially extended mass can be written simply as a vector sum over point masses. In the [[continuum limit]], this becomes an integral over the density <math>\rho~</math>, and if the deflection is small we can approximate the gravitational potential along the deflected trajectory by the potential along the undeflected trajectory, as in the [[Born approximation]] in quantum mechanics. The deflection is then
<math>\vec{\hat{\alpha}}(\vec{\xi})=\frac{4 G}{c^2} \int d^2\xi^{\prime} \int dz \rho(\vec{\xi}^{\prime},z) \frac{\vec{b}}{|\vec{b}|^2}, ~ \vec{b} \equiv \vec{\xi} - \vec{\xi^{\prime}} </math>
where <math>z</math> is the line-of-sight coordinate, and <math> \vec{b} </math> is the vector impact parameter of the actual ray path from the infinitesimal mass <math> d^2\xi^{\prime} dz\rho(\vec{\xi}^{\prime},z) </math> located at the coordinates <math>(\vec{\xi}^{\prime}, z)</math>.<ref>{{ cite journal | last = Bartelmann| first = M. |author2=Schneider, P. |date=January 2001 | title=Weak Gravitational Lensing| journal = Physics Reports | volume=340 | issue = 4–5 |pages = 291–472 | bibcode = 2001PhR...340..291B | doi = 10.1016/S0370-1573(00)00082-X|arxiv = astro-ph/9912508 }}</ref>
== Thin lens approximation ==
In the limit of a "thin lens", where the distances between the source, lens, and observer are much larger than the size of the lens (this is almost always true for astronomical objects), we can define the projected mass density
<math>\Sigma(\vec{\xi})=\int \rho(\vec{\xi},z) dz </math>
where <math>\vec{\xi}</math> is a vector in the plane of the sky. The deflection angle is then
<math>\vec{\hat{\alpha}}= \frac{4 G}{c^2} \int \frac{(\vec{\xi}-\vec{\xi}^{\prime})\Sigma(\vec{\xi}^{\prime})}{|\vec{\xi}-\vec{\xi}^{\prime}|^2}d^2 \xi^{\prime}</math>
[[Image:Gravitational-lensing-angles.png|right|frame|Angles involved in a thin gravitational lens system.]]
As shown in the diagram on the right, the difference between the unlensed angular position <math>\vec{\beta}</math> and the observed position <math>\vec{\theta}</math> is this deflection angle, reduced by a ratio of distances, described as the lens equation
<math>\vec{\beta}=\vec{\theta}-\vec{\alpha}(\vec{\theta}) = \vec{\theta} - \frac{D_{ds}}{D_s} \vec{\hat{\alpha}}(\vec{D_d\theta})</math>
where <math>D_{ds}~</math> is the distance from the lens to the source <math>D_s~</math> is the distance from the observer to the source, and <math>D_d~</math> is the distance from the observer to the lens. For extragalactic lenses, these must be [[angular diameter distance]]s.
In strong gravitational lensing, this equation can have multiple solutions, because a single source at <math>\vec{\beta}</math> can be lensed into multiple images.
=== Convergence and deflection potential ===
It is convenient to define the ''convergence''
<math> \kappa(\vec{\theta}) = \frac{\Sigma(D_d\vec{\theta})}{\Sigma_{cr}} </math>
and the ''critical surface density'' (not to be confused with the [[Critical density (cosmology)|critical density]] of the universe)
<math> \Sigma_{cr} = \frac{c^2 D_s}{4\pi G D_{ds}D_d} </math>
The reduced deflection angle <math>\vec{\alpha}(\vec{\theta})</math> can now be written as
<math> \vec{\alpha}(\vec{\theta}) = \frac{1}{\pi}\int d^2 \theta^{\prime} \frac{(\vec{\theta}-\vec{\theta}^{\prime})\kappa(\vec{\theta}^{\prime})}{|\vec{\theta}-\vec{\theta}^{\prime}|^2} </math>
We can also define the ''deflection potential''
<math> \psi(\vec{\theta}) = \frac{1}{\pi}\int d^2 \theta^{\prime} \kappa(\vec{\theta}^{\prime}) \ln |\vec{\theta}-\vec{\theta}^{\prime}| </math>
such that the scaled deflection angle is just the [[gradient]] of the potential and the convergence is half the [[Laplacian]] of the potential:
<math> \vec{\alpha}(\vec{\theta}) = \vec{\nabla} \psi(\vec{\theta}) </math>
<math> \kappa(\vec{\theta}) = \frac{1}{2} \nabla^2 \psi(\vec{\theta}) </math>
The deflection potential can also be written as a scaled projection of the Newtonian gravitational potential <math>\Phi~</math> of the lens<ref>{{ cite arxiv | last = Narayan| first = R. | last2 = Bartelmann |first2=M. |date=June 1996 | title=Lectures on Gravitational Lensing |arxiv = astro-ph/9606001 }}</ref>
<math> \psi(\vec{\theta}) = \frac{2 D_{ds}}{D_d D_s c^2} \int \Phi(D_d\vec{\theta},z) dz </math>
=== Lensing Jacobian ===
The [[Jacobian matrix and determinant|Jacobian]] between the unlensed and lensed coordinate systems is
<math>A_{ij}=\frac{\partial \beta_i}{\partial \theta_j}=\delta_{ij} - \frac{\partial \alpha_i}{\partial \theta_j} = \delta_{ij} - \frac{\partial^2 \psi}{\partial \theta_i \partial \theta_j}</math>
where <math>\delta_{ij}~</math> is the [[Kronecker delta]]. Because the matrix of second derivatives must be symmetric, the Jacobian can be decomposed into a diagonal term involving the convergence and a [[matrix trace|trace]]-free term involving the ''shear'' <math>\gamma~</math>
<math>A=(1-\kappa)\left[\begin{array}{ c c } 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{array}\right]-\gamma\left[\begin{array}{ c c } \cos 2\phi & \sin 2\phi \\ \sin 2\phi & -\cos 2\phi \end{array}\right]</math>
where <math>\phi~</math> is the angle between <math>\vec{\alpha}</math> and the x-axis. The term involving the convergence magnifies the image by increasing its size while conserving surface brightness. The term involving the shear stretches the image [[tangent]]ially around the lens, as discussed in [[#Weak lensing observables|weak lensing observables]].
The shear defined here is ''not'' equivalent to the [[shear mapping|shear]] traditionally defined in mathematics, though both stretch an image non-uniformly.
[[Image:shear-components.svg|right|thumb|300px|Effect of the components of convergence and shear on a circular source represented by the solid green circle. The complex shear notation is defined [[#Shear and reduced shear|below]].]]
=== Fermat surface ===
There is an alternative way of deriving the lens equation, starting from the photon arrival time (Fermat surface)
<math> t = \int_{0}^{z_s} { n dz \over c \cos \alpha(z) } </math>
where <math> dz/c </math> is the time to travel an infinitesimal line element along the source-observer straight line in vacuum, which is then corrected by the factor
<math> 1/\cos(\alpha(z)) \approx 1 + {\alpha(z)^2 \over 2} </math>
to get the line element along the bended path <math> dl = {dz \over c \cos \alpha(z) } </math> with a varying small pitch angle <math> \alpha(z), </math> and the refraction index {{math|''n''}} for the "aether", i.e., the gravitational field. The last can be obtained from the fact that a photon travels on a null geodesic of a weakly perturbed static Minkowski universe
<math> ds^2 = 0 = c^2 dt^2 \left(1 + {2 \Phi \over c^2} \right) - \left(1 + {2 \Phi \over c^2} \right)^{-1} dl^2 </math>
where the uneven gravitational potential <math> \Phi \ll c^2 </math> drives a changing the speed of light
<math> c' = {dl/dt} = \left(1 + {2 \Phi \over c^2} \right) c. </math>
So the refraction index
<math> n \equiv {c \over c'} \approx \left(1 - {2 \Phi \over c^2} \right). </math>
The refraction index greater than unity because of the negative gravitational potential <math> \Phi </math>.
Put these together and keep the leading terms we have the time arrival surface
<math> t \approx \int_0^{z_s} {dz \over c} + \int_0^{z_s} {dz \over c} {\alpha(z)^2 \over 2} - \int_0^{z_s} {dz \over c} {2 \Phi \over c^2} . </math>
The first term is the straight path travel time, the second term is the extra geometric path, and the third is the gravitational delay. Make the triangle approximation that <math> \alpha(z) = \theta - \beta </math> for the path between the observer and the lens, and <math> \alpha(z) \approx (\theta - \beta) {D_d \over D_{ds}} </math> for the path between the lens and the source. The geometric delay term becomes
<math> {D_d \over c} { (\vec{\theta} - \vec{\beta})^2 \over 2} + {D_{ds} \over c} { \left[ (\vec{\theta} - \vec{\beta} ) {D_d \over D_{ds}} \right]^2 \over 2} = {D_d D_s \over D_{ds} } { ( \vec{\theta} - \vec{\beta} )^2 \over 2} . </math> (How? There is no D_s on the left. Angular diameter distances don't add in a simple way, in general.) So the Fermat surface becomes
<math> t = constant + {D_d D_s \over D_{ds} c} \tau, ~ \tau \equiv \left[ { (\vec{\theta}-\vec{\beta})^2 \over 2} - \psi \right] </math>
where <math> \tau </math> is so-called dimensionless time delay, and the 2D lensing potential
<math> \psi(\vec{\theta}) = \frac{2 D_{ds}}{D_d D_s c^2} \int \Phi(D_d\vec{\theta},z) dz. </math>
The images lie at the extrema of this surface, so the variation of t with <math> \vec{\theta} </math> is zero,
<math> 0 = \nabla_{\vec{\theta}} \tau = \vec{\theta} - \vec{\beta} - \nabla_{\vec{\theta}} \psi(\vec{\theta}) </math>
which is the lens equation. Take the Poisson's equation for 3D potential <math> \Phi(\vec{\xi}) = - \int \frac{d^3\xi^{\prime} \rho(\vec{\xi}^{\prime})}{|\vec{\xi}-\vec{\xi}^{\prime}|} </math>
and we find the 2D lensing potential
<math>\psi(\vec{\theta}) = - \frac{2 G D_{ds}}{D_d D_s c^2} \int dz \int \frac{d^3\xi^{\prime} \rho(\vec{\xi}^{\prime})}{|\vec{\xi}-\vec{\xi}^{\prime}|} = - \sum_i \frac{2 G M_i D_{is} }{D_s D_i c^2} \left[ \sinh^{-1} { |z -D_i| \over D_i |\vec{\theta}-\vec{\theta}_i | } \right ] |_{D_i}^{D_s} + |_{D_i}^{0} . </math>
Here we assumed the lens is a collection of point masses <math> M_i </math> at angular coordinates <math> \vec{\theta}_i </math> and distances <math> z=D_i .</math> Use <math> \sinh^{-1} 1/x = \ln(1/x + \sqrt{1/x^2+1}) \approx -\ln(x/2) </math> for very small {{math|''x''}} we find
<math> \psi(\vec{\theta}) \approx \sum_i \frac{2 GM_i D_{is} }{D_s D_i c^2} \left[ \ln\left( { |\vec{\theta}-\vec{\theta}_i |^2 \over 4} { D_i \over D_{is} } \right) \right]. </math>
One can compute the ''convergence'' by applying the 2D Laplacian of the 2D lensing potential
<math> \kappa(\vec{\theta}) = \frac{1}{2} \nabla_{\vec{\theta}}^2 \psi(\vec{\theta}) = \frac{4\pi G D_{ds}D_d} {c^2 D_s} \int dz \rho( D_d \vec{\theta},z) == {\Sigma \over \Sigma_{cr} } == \sum_i { 4\pi G M_i D_{is} \over c^2 D_i D_s} \delta(\vec{\theta}-\vec{\theta}_i) </math>
in agreement with earlier definition <math> \kappa(\vec{\theta}) = {\Sigma \over \Sigma_{cr} }</math> as the ratio of projected density with the critical density. Here we used <math> \nabla^2 1/r = - 4 \pi \delta(r) </math> and <math> \nabla_{\vec{\theta}} = D_d \nabla. </math>
We can also confirm the previously defined reduced deflection angle
<math> \vec{\theta} -\vec{\beta} = \nabla_{\vec{\theta}} \psi(\vec{\theta}) = \sum_i { \theta_{Ei}^2 \over |\vec{\theta}-\vec{\theta}_i |} , ~ \pi \theta_{Ei}^2 \equiv {4 \pi GM_i D_{is} \over c^2 D_s D_i } </math>
where <math> \theta_{Ei} </math> is the so-called Einstein angular radius of a point lens Mi. For a single point lens at the origin we recover the standard result that there will be two images at the two solutions of the essentially quadratic equation
<math> \vec{\theta} -\vec{\beta} = {\theta_{E}^2 \over |\vec{\theta} |}. </math>
The amplification matrix can be obtained by double derivatives of the dimensionless time delay
<math> A_{ij} = {\partial \beta_j \over \partial \theta_i} = {\partial \tau \over \partial \theta_i \partial \theta_j } = \delta_{ij} - {\partial \psi \over \partial \theta_i \partial \theta_j } = \left[\begin{array}{ c c } 1-\kappa -\gamma_1 & \gamma_2 \\ \gamma_2 & 1-\kappa +\gamma_1 \end{array}\right] </math>
where we have define the derivatives
<math> \kappa = {\partial \psi \over 2 \partial \theta_1 \partial \theta_1 } + {\partial \psi \over 2\partial \theta_2 \partial \theta_2 } , ~ \gamma_1 \equiv {\partial \psi \over 2 \partial \theta_1 \partial \theta_1 } - {\partial \psi \over 2\partial \theta_2 \partial \theta_2 } , ~ \gamma_2 \equiv {\partial \psi \over \partial \theta_1 \partial \theta_2 } </math>
which takes the meaning of convergence and shear. The amplification is the inverse of the Jacobian
<math> A = 1/det(A_{ij}) = {1 \over (1-\kappa)^2 -\gamma_1^2 -\gamma_2^2} </math>
where a positive A means either a maxima or a minima, and a negative A means a saddle point in the arrival surface.
For a single point lens, one can show (albeit a lengthy calculation) that
<math> \kappa =0, ~ \gamma = \sqrt{\gamma_1^2 + \gamma_2^2} = {\theta_E^2 \over |\theta|^2}, ~ \theta_E^2= {4GM D_{ds} \over c^2 D_dD_s}. </math>
So the amplification of a point lens is given by
<math> A = \left( 1 - {\theta_E^4 \over \theta^4} \right)^{-1}. </math>
Note A diverges for images at the Einstein radius <math> \theta_E. </math>
In cases there are multiple point lenses plus a smooth background of (dark) particles of surface density <math>\Sigma_{\rm cr} \kappa_{\rm smooth}, </math> the time arrival surface is
<math> \psi(\vec{\theta}) \approx {1 \over 2} \kappa_{\rm smooth} |\theta|^2 + \sum_i \theta_E^2 \left[ \ln\left( { |\vec{\theta}-\vec{\theta}_i |^2 \over 4} { D_d \over D_{ds} } \right) \right]. </math>
To compute the amplification, e.g., at the origin (0,0), due to identical point masses distributed at <math> (\theta_{xi},\theta_{yi} ) </math> we have to add up the total shear, and include a convergence of the smooth background, <math> A = \left[ (1 - \kappa_{\rm smooth})^2 - \left( \sum_i { (\theta_{xi}^2 - \theta_{yi}^2 ) \theta_E^2 \over (\theta_{xi}^2 + \theta_{yi}^2)^2 }\right) ^2 - \left( \sum_i { (2 \theta_{xi} \theta_{yi}) \theta_E^2 \over (\theta_{xi}^2 + \theta_{yi}^2)^2 } \right)^2 \right] ^{-1} </math>
This generally creates a network of critical curves, lines connecting image points of infinite amplification.
== General weak lensing ==
In [[Weak gravitational lensing#Cosmic shear|weak lensing by large-scale structure]], the thin-lens approximation may break down, and low-density extended structures may not be well approximated by multiple thin-lens planes. In this case, the deflection can be derived by instead assuming that the gravitational potential is slowly varying everywhere (for this reason, this approximation is not valid for strong lensing). This approach assumes the universe is well described by a Newtonian-perturbed [[FRW metric]], but it makes no other assumptions about the distribution of the lensing mass.
As in the thin-lens case, the effect can be written as a mapping from the unlensed angular position <math>\vec{\beta}</math> to the lensed position <math>\vec{\theta}</math>. The [[Jacobian matrix and determinant|Jacobian]] of the transform can be written as an integral over the gravitational potential <math>\Phi~</math> along the line of sight <ref>{{cite book |title=Modern Cosmology|last=Dodelson|first=Scott|date=2003|publisher=[[Academic Press]]|location=Amsterdam|isbn=0-12-219141-2}}</ref>
<math> \frac{\partial \beta_i}{\partial \theta_j} = \delta_{ij} + \int_0^{r_\infty} dr g(r) \frac{\partial^2 \Phi(\vec{x}(r))}{\partial x^i \partial x^j} </math>
where <math>r~</math> is the [[comoving distance]], <math>x^i~</math> are the transverse distances, and
<math> g(r) = 2 r \int^{r_\infty}_r dr' \left(1-\frac{r^\prime}{r}\right)W(r^\prime) </math>
is the ''lensing kernel'', which defines the efficiency of lensing for a distribution of sources <math>W(r)~</math>.
The Jacobian <math>A_{ij}~</math> can be decomposed into convergence and shear terms just as with the thin-lens case, and in the limit of a lens that is both thin and weak, their physical interpretations are the same.
== Weak lensing observables ==
In [[weak gravitational lensing]], the [[Gravitational Lensing Formalism#Lensing Jacobian|Jacobian]] is mapped out by observing the effect of the shear on the ellipticities of background galaxies. This effect is purely statistical; the shape of any galaxy will be dominated by its random, unlensed shape, but lensing will produce a spatially coherent distortion of these shapes.
=== Measures of ellipticity ===
In most fields of astronomy, the ellipticity is defined as <math>1-q~</math>, where <math>q=\frac{b}{a}</math> is the axis ratio of the [[ellipse]]. In [[weak gravitational lensing]], two different definitions are commonly used, and both are complex quantities which specify both the axis ratio and the position angle <math>\phi~</math>:
<math> \chi = \frac{1-q^2}{1+q^2}e^{2i\phi} = \frac{a^2-b^2}{a^2+b^2}e^{2i\phi} </math>
<math> \epsilon = \frac{1-q}{1+q}e^{2i\phi} = \frac{a-b}{a+b}e^{2i\phi} </math>
Like the traditional ellipticity, the magnitudes of both of these quantities range from 0 (circular) to 1 (a line segment). The position angle is encoded in the complex phase, but because of the factor of 2 in the trigonometric arguments, ellipticity is invariant under a rotation of 180 degrees. This is to be expected; an ellipse is unchanged by a 180° rotation. Taken as imaginary and real parts, the real part of the complex ellipticity describes the elongation along the coordinate axes, while the imaginary part describes the elongation at 45° from the axes.
The ellipticity is often written as a two-component vector instead of a complex number, though it is not a true [[Coordinate vector|vector]] with regard to transforms:
<math> \chi = \{\left|\chi\right|\cos 2\phi, \left|\chi\right|\sin 2\phi\} </math>
<math> \epsilon = \{\left|\epsilon\right|\cos 2\phi, \left|\epsilon\right| \sin 2\phi\} </math>
Real astronomical background sources are not perfect ellipses. Their ellipticities can be measured by finding a best-fit elliptical model to the data, or by measuring the second moments of the image about some [[centroid]] <math>(\bar{x},\bar{y})</math>
<math> q_{xx} = \frac{\sum (x-\bar{x})^2 I(x,y)}{\sum I(x,y)} </math>
<math> q_{yy} = \frac{\sum (y-\bar{y})^2 I(x,y)}{\sum I(x,y)} </math>
<math> q_{xy} = \frac{\sum (x-\bar{x})(y-\bar{y}) I(x,y)}{\sum I(x,y)} </math>
The complex ellipticities are then
<math> \chi = \frac{q_{xx}-q_{yy} + 2 i q_{xy}}{q_{xx}+q_{yy}} </math>
<math> \epsilon = \frac{q_{xx}-q_{yy} + 2 i q_{xy}}{q_{xx}+q_{yy} + 2\sqrt{q_{xx}q_{yy}-q_{xy}^2}} </math>
This can be used to relate the second moments to traditional ellipse parameters:
<math> q_{xx} = a^2 \cos^2 \theta + b^2 \sin^2 \theta\, </math>
<math> q_{yy} = a^2 \sin^2 \theta + b^2 \cos^2 \theta\, </math>
<math> q_{xy} = (a^2-b^2)\sin \theta \cos \theta\, </math>
and in reverse:
<math> a^2 = \frac{q_{xx}+q_{yy} + \sqrt{(q_{xx}-q_{yy})^2 + 4q_{xy}^2}}{2} </math>
<math> b^2 = \frac{q_{xx}+q_{yy} - \sqrt{(q_{xx}-q_{yy})^2 + 4q_{xy}^2}}{2} </math>
<math> \tan 2\theta = \frac{2q_{xy}}{q_{xx}-q_{yy}} </math>
The unweighted second moments above are problematic in the presence of noise, neighboring objects, or extended galaxy profiles, so it is typical to use [[apodization|apodized]] moments instead:
<math> q_{xx} = \frac{\sum (x-\bar{x})^2 w(x-\bar{x},y-\bar{y}) I(x,y)}{\sum w(x-\bar{x},y-\bar{y}) I(x,y)} </math>
<math> q_{yy} = \frac{\sum (y-\bar{y})^2 w(x-\bar{x},y-\bar{y}) I(x,y)}{\sum w(x-\bar{x},y-\bar{y}) I(x,y)} </math>
<math> q_{xy} = \frac{\sum (x-\bar{x})(y-\bar{y}) w(x-\bar{x},y-\bar{y}) I(x,y)}{\sum w(x-\bar{x},y-\bar{y}) I(x,y)} </math>
Here <math>w(x,y)~</math> is a weight function that typically goes to zero or quickly approaches zero at some finite radius.
Image moments cannot generally be used to measure the ellipticity of galaxies without correcting for [[Weak gravitational lensing#Methodology|observational effects]], particularly the [[point spread function]].<ref>{{ cite journal | last = Bernstein| first = G. |author2=Jarvis, M. |date=February 2002 | title=Shapes and Shears, Stars and Smears: Optimal Measurements for Weak Lensing| journal = Astronomical Journal | volume=123 | issue = 2 |pages = 583–618 | bibcode = 2002AJ....123..583B | doi = 10.1086/338085|arxiv = astro-ph/0107431 }}</ref>
=== Shear and reduced shear ===
Recall that the [[Gravitational Lensing Formalism#Lensing Jacobian|lensing Jacobian]] can be decomposed into shear <math>\gamma~</math> and convergence <math>\kappa~</math>. Acting on a circular background source with radius <math>R~</math>, lensing generates an ellipse with major and minor axes
<math>a = \frac{R}{1-\kappa-\gamma}</math>
<math>b = \frac{R}{1-\kappa+\gamma}</math>
as long as the shear and convergence do not change appreciably over the size of the source (in that case, the lensed image is not an ellipse). Galaxies are not intrinsically circular, however, so it is necessary to quantify the effect of lensing on a non-zero ellipticity.
We can define the ''complex shear'' in analogy to the complex ellipticities defined above
<math> \gamma = \left|\gamma\right| e^{2i\phi} </math>
as well as the ''reduced shear''
<math> g \equiv \frac{\gamma}{1-\kappa} </math>
The lensing Jacobian can now be written as
<math> A=\left[\begin{array}{ c c } 1 - \kappa - \mathrm{Re}[\gamma] & -\mathrm{Im}[\gamma] \\ -\mathrm{Im}[\gamma] & 1 -\kappa + \mathrm{Re}[\gamma]\end{array}\right] =(1-\kappa)\left[\begin{array}{ c c } 1-\mathrm{Re}[g] & -\mathrm{Im}[g] \\ -\mathrm{Im}[g] & 1+ \mathrm{Re}[g]\end{array}\right] </math>
For a reduced shear <math>g~</math> and unlensed complex ellipticities <math>\chi_s~</math> and <math>\epsilon_s~</math>, the lensed ellipticities are
<math> \chi = \frac{\chi_s+2g+g^2\chi_s^*}{1+|g|^2 + 2\mathrm{Re}(g\chi_s^*)} </math>
<math> \epsilon = \frac{\epsilon_s+g}{1+g^*\epsilon_s} </math>
In the weak lensing limit, <math>\gamma \ll 1</math> and <math>\kappa \ll 1</math>, so
<math> \chi \approx \chi_s+2g \approx \chi_s+2\gamma </math>
<math> \epsilon \approx \epsilon_s+g \approx \epsilon_s+\gamma </math>
If we can assume that the sources are randomly oriented, their complex ellipticities average to zero, so <math> \langle \chi \rangle = 2\langle \gamma \rangle </math> and <math>\langle \epsilon \rangle = \langle \gamma \rangle</math>. This is the principal equation of weak lensing: the average ellipticity of background galaxies is a direct measure of the shear induced by foreground mass.
=== Magnification ===
While gravitational lensing preserves surface brightness, as dictated by [[Liouville's theorem (Hamiltonian)|Liouville's theorem]], lensing does change the apparent [[solid angle]] of a source. The amount of [[magnification]] is given by the ratio of the image area to the source area. For a circularly [[symmetry|symmetric]] lens, the magnification factor μ is given by
<math> \mu = \frac{\theta}{\beta} \frac{d\theta}{d\beta} </math>
In terms of convergence and shear
<math> \mu = \frac{1}{\det A} = \frac{1}{[(1-\kappa)^2-\gamma^2]} </math>
For this reason, the Jacobian <math>A~</math> is also known as the "inverse magnification matrix".
The reduced shear is invariant with the scaling of the Jacobian <math>A~</math> by a scalar <math>\lambda~</math>, which is equivalent to the transformations <math> 1-\kappa^{\prime} = \lambda(1-\kappa) </math> and <math> \gamma^{\prime} = \lambda \gamma </math>.
Thus, <math>\kappa</math> can only be determined up to a transformation <math>\kappa \rightarrow \lambda \kappa+(1-\lambda)</math>, which is known as the "mass sheet degeneracy." In principle, this degeneracy can be broken if an independent measurement of the magnification is available because the magnification is not invariant under the aforementioned degeneracy transformation. Specifically, <math>\mu~</math> scales with <math>\lambda~</math> as <math>\mu \propto \lambda^{-2}</math>.
